awd_titl_txt: FMitF: Collaborative Research: Track I: Predictive Online Safety Analysis from Multi-hop State Estimates for High-autonomy on Highways
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to bring safety assurance to autonomous and semi-autonomous vehicles. The approach is to lengthen the time that a car can predict its driving path, and share this path with surrounding vehicles. With these expanded predictions, it is possible to estimate the current and future behaviors of vehicles, according to their design models. Currently, online formal safety analysis can promise guarantees and oversight, but overly conservative approaches can lead to bad driving. This is in contrast to the use of test-driving data and machine learning to build driving models, which are difficult to analyze. The project aims to discover the right balance by computationally (1) estimating the current state of the autonomous vehicle and its multi-hop environment from sensor data, (2) predicting vehicle trajectories 4-6 seconds into future, and (3) checking the models and predictions---all in milliseconds. A new scientific workshop will be created to explore similar issues in autonomy, in addition to a new undergraduate course on autonomy.

The project aims to deliver (1) new sensor-fusion algorithms over Vehicle-to-Infrastructure/Vehicle (V2X) systems, (2) a first-of-its-kind open, machine-interpretable library of agent models for driving predictions, (3) algorithms for model identification, and (4) algorithms for checking safety online. These modules will be integrated in an end-to-end system --- OmniVisor --- and evaluated in realistic accident-prone scenarios with real vehicles in University of Michigan's Mcity facility. The research will build connections across the disciplines of formal methods, hybrid dynamical systems, estimation and detection theory, and mobile networking. If successful OmniVisor will provide a scientific basis for obtaining safety assurances for vehicles in mixed-autonomy scenarios and experimentally demonstrate the approach on the road with real vehicles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project at the intersection of formal methods and signal processing, investigated the design and analysis of certain key components in autonomous vehicles from the point of view of safety and novel sensing paradigms. Specific advances were made in the technical problem of controller design and the problem of source separation with audio signals. 

Controller design is a fundamental and challenging problem, particularly for complex environments like urban driving. This project developed a new algorithm called FACTEST that can be used to synthesize controllers for vehicles in dynamic environments, with provable guarantees, and it was then extended to support control tasks that may extend to infinite time horizons and uncertain perception. For example, FACTEST can automatically generate the controller for a robot to visit certain important locations and charging stations forever, while avoiding collisions and even in cases where the robot may have complicated physics. FACTEST can also work with imperfect sensing. This algorithm also runs faster than other state of the art methods, because it does not rely on breaking-up the search space into tiny fragments (discretization-free). 

Imperfect sensing can compromise safety in autonomous systems. This project explored how sound can play an important role in localizing surrounding vehicles. Moreover, if vehicles are augmented with more capable acoustic sensors, then perhaps pedestrian and other unstructured sounds can also be analyzed, improving the overall situational awareness of the vehicle. This project developed algorithms for "unmixing" sound signals using small microphones (source-separation) as a building-block towards this bigger goal.

The project showed that the ability to rotate the mic can fundamentally improve the quality of the solution for the source separation problem. The proposed algorithm Rotation Induced Aliasing for Audio Source Separation (ROSS) has theoretical convergence guarantees and shows substantial performance improvements in common scenarios. This led the project to the threshold of designing safe systems that are cognizant of the convergence (or lack thereof) of the sensing modules, but this will require further investigations.

The project led to the creation of the GRAIC autonomous racing competition which ran for 3 years as part of one of the leading conferences (CPS-IoT Week). There is a well-recognized scarcity of benchmark controllers for autonomous cars and without appropriate benchmarks, the technologies for testing and verification cannot advance. Using the competition as an incentive, the team was able to collect well-designed controller programs which can be used for future research in testing, verification, and simulation.

The project supported three PhD students through different stages of their doctoral studies. Two of these students will complete their PhDs in 2024. The project also supported the PIs in advancing their educational missions. For example, a course on "Safe Autonomy" was developed by the PI at Illinois. The students learn the fundamental algorithms for autonomous systems and then get to experience deploying their code on a full-sized car. The supporting software infrastructure developed for this course enables more than sixty students to get this experience every semester. 

ROSS: https://uiuc-ss.github.io/RoSS/

GRAIC: https://popgri.github.io/Race/index.html

FACTEST: https://github.com/kmmille/FACTEST
